title: Submit July 5–August 4 Athena credit card liquidation - via [Accounts Payable email re: Submission of BREX Credit Card Liquidation - July 2025](missive://mail.missiveapp.com/#inbox/conversations/e90f2efc-3294-456e-be35-5e535727e830)
content:
**Message URL:** 
[missive://mail.missiveapp.com/#inbox/conversations/e90f2efc-3294-456e-be35-5e535727e830](missive://mail.missiveapp.com/#inbox/conversations/e90f2efc-3294-456e-be35-5e535727e830)  

---  

## Email

**Datetime**:
2025-08-13 8:15 AM America/New_York

**From**:
Accounts Payable <ap@athenago.com>

**To**:


**Body**:
Good day!

  
Hope you are doing well.

  
This is a gentle reminder regarding the credit card liquidation for you or your cardholder for the period **July 5, 2025 to August 4, 2025**_._ 

Kindly fill out the[ expense tracker](https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1pbfq7f8NJ4Y0SXBs4NOugJ8h5ahbiw7y88XqPq2fMjw/edit#gid=0) with your itemized transactions and send it via [Credit Card Expense Report Form.](https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLScUapXHo8X4t2iK2syuHkpsD270GukknqSivjFxhkpWLUFBTQ/viewform)

  
_Note: For C-suites, If the monthly credit card expense report is $5,000 and below, there is no need to route it to the CEO for approval. To complete the liquidation submission, the C-suite cardholder must acknowledge the expense report via email, and his/her XP uploads the copy through the mentioned form._

Please be informed that the statement cut-off date is every 5th of the month. Hence, the deadline for submitting credit card liquidation is every 15th of the month.

  
We appreciate your compliance by **Tuesday**. Kindly disregard this email if you have already submitted it.

  
For more information about our corporate credit card liquidation process, kindly take the time to read our [policy](https://drive.google.com/file/d/1gkKrPKlLFkMR3TRA3V7a575SYWEbTlcq/view).

  
Should you have any questions or concerns, please let us know.
  
  
Warm regards,

  
**Accounts Payable** 

Finance Department, Athena

**Message URL:** 
[missive://mail.missiveapp.com/#inbox/conversations/95b637a9-7e69-4b24-8209-f6c1cb420853](missive://mail.missiveapp.com/#inbox/conversations/95b637a9-7e69-4b24-8209-f6c1cb420853)  

---  

## Email

**Datetime**:
2025-08-07 8:00 AM America/New_York

**From**:
Kristen Berman <kristen@irrationallabs.com>

**To**:
Kristen Berman <kristen@irrationallabs.com>

**Body**:
# **Hi Inner Circle!**

  
You're reading this because you're part of the Irrational Labs journey – either as a friend or as a client who's worked with us multiple times. And because I like you. 

  
**Too busy? tl;dr: Stuff going well. Would love intros to people who have sold/purchased consulting firms. Scroll to the end for baby pics.** 

## 

## **Personal Updates**

  
**Baby #2:** Kepler arrived three months ago!Pictures below. I took 3 months maternity leave and came back to find sales on target for 2025 and a happy staff -- 100% of people said they had no plans to leave in the next year.

  
**Radish v2.0:** If you didn’t know, Phil and I live in a[ compound with 20 people and 8 kids under four ](https://kristenberman.substack.com/p/radish-oakland-how-does-a-behavioral)yrs old in Oakland. But we’re outgrowing this. And we like to do crazy projects. So we bought a waterfront property in Alameda with goal to move in 2027\. It has an existing duplex on it and we plan to build 4 more homes that our friends will buy. We submitted plans last week under the new CA law SB684\. We may be the first in the East Bay to use this law. #yimby

## 

## **Business Updates**

Overall, we had a slow February (no sales) and our team was worried that AI was the culprit. But then we had an amazing Q2 and are set up for an even better Q3\. 

  
Our sales cycle is 60 days. 25% of our sales in 2025 are new logos - this is pretty consistent with prior years. Each quarter we’re writing about \~30 proposals. Our win rate is \~40%. These numbers seem reasonable to me but flag if you have benchmarks - basically our business is based on us doing good work and people hiring us again and again. 

  
**Strong Momentum:**

* **We’re getting some solid top of funnel opportunities:**
   * Insight Partners asked me to tag team with them on a talk to their portfolio companies on AI pricing (60 b2b companies came)
   * 450 people signed up to our event "The 7 Deadly Sins of AI Adoption"
   * I’m speaking at HubSpot's conference, Inbound, on the topic of AI adoption
   * We are doing talks for Vimeo, JP Morgan, BBC and we will be at Finnovate
   * [My substack](https://kristenberman.substack.com/) is going well -- if you haven’t subscribed, wtf.
  
* **AI in the workplace (aka: “My employees should be using AI and they are not”)**
   * I remain bullish that our team should be playing here. This is basically “digital transformation” type work. But progress has been slow (not finding decision makers with budgets) and our offering will need to evolve rapidly as the market does. That said, we signed deals with AWS and Intuit for behavior change programs. So it’s starting. We are in the midst of delivering.
  
* **Repeat business is working:**
   * A Place for Mom has a retainer and expanded to another team
   * PayPal and Discover each have two active workstreams
   * Intuit spent some end of quarter budget with us
   * LinkedIn signed up for another project
  
* **We’re getting killer talent**
   * We hired the former head of behavioral science at Indeed (she turned down an offer from Indeed and Stanford to work with us)
   * We recruited 3 more behavioral scientists to do a trial with us and all 3 are rockstars. If I wasn’t risk averse on over-hiring, we would immediately make offers to all of them. The best in the field want to work with us. And they all are delightful to be around, so culture is up.
   * Our sales leader left last year and we had a gap. She was fine but not A+. But we have filled it with two part time leaders. Both are A+ players. One is a behavioral scientist herself and the other used to work for us in 2021\. It’s hard to sell behavioral science since no one really knows what we do -- but these guys are cranking

## 

## **Current Thinking**

  
**Book Contract:** Should I write a book? My proposal on everyday behavior change was accepted by Author's Equity (James Clear's publisher). Is writing a book in the year 2025 worth it? Hat tip to Dan Ariely who is really helping me think through the topic. 

  
**I am on a GLP-1:** This is the most significant behavior change tool in history. And I had to try it! Because I had 20 lbs of postpartum weight -- I thought why not?! And it’s wild - wow. I'm eating 80% less without additional willpower. 

We never made progress on our sales push to Roche in 2024\. But I’ll try again. We’ll use my hands-on experience to pitch Ro, Hims & Hers, and Roche. Companies that solve the psychological piece will win on adherence. 

  
**Started Vibe Coding:** I coded a mobile web app on Maternity leave. Really empowering to do the E2E flows for this (and harder in many ways than the internet sells vibecoding). And like GLP-1s, never let a good experience go to waste -- I'm using this to pitch Claude and OpenAI on better onboarding for non-technical builders.

  
**Spotlight Effect:** If you didn’t know I was pregnant, you weren’t alone. I hid my pregnancy for 6 months to test how long I could go unnoticed. Even gaining 15 pounds, people at Radish didn't notice. [Here is the 1 min video of the reveal! ](https://drive.google.com/file/d/1ewnsJadWnIGmZ8lGua-nj65oDqyfR4Wl/view?usp=drive%5Flink)Crazy huh? We're all focused on our own narratives and miss obvious changes in others. This is actually quite relaxing. No one really cares if your socks don’t match or your fly is undone - because they don’t notice. 

## 

## **What I Need: How do I think about exit (long term)?**

This is an interesting one. I don't want to exit Irrational Labs now (we have a killer team and have grown the business every year for the last 7 years) but I find myself wondering what an exit path could look like. 

  
Do we sell the whole business? (to another consulting firm? Someone else?) What should we be doing now to make the company more valuable for a future sale event? 

  
I'm looking for connections to people who can help me think through this – e.g. people have exited/sold a consulting firm, firms th

He suggests involving Arthur as this relates to the CRM infrastructure development. Chris had previously outlined two Google Workspace options for managing bespoke email addresses for updates, comparing Google Groups and Individual Google Workspace accounts, detailing their pros, cons, and automation potential. Jake implies readiness to proceed with setting up email infrastructure integrated with AI parsing of updates and requests access to a Powerset Google Workspace admin account, an OAuth client with specific API scopes, and a list of emails for initial setup.

# Autodelegator AI Action Items 

**Action Items (Detected):**
Coordinate with Jake to schedule a meeting upon his return Monday in San Francisco to discuss update collection and CRM integration. Facilitate inclusion of Arthur in the discussion as indicated. Provide or arrange access to a Powerset Google Workspace admin account with full privileges. Set up or assist in setting up an OAuth client with directory/identity/admin API scopes in Google Cloud. Compile and supply the initial list of email addresses for the bespoke address setup.

**Above and Beyond Action Items (Optional):**
1. Prepare a detailed implementation plan in Notion or Coda outlining the setup of Google Workspace accounts and API integrations to ensure smooth execution and track progress.

2. Analyze how AI parsing could be best integrated with the CRM system using Airtable or Google Sheets to maximize update efficiency and strategic follow-on actions.

What are the best methods to automate and secure the integration of AI-parsed email updates into CRM platforms using Google Workspace APIs and workflow automation tools?

**Original Email:** 
Thanks, Chris!

I'm back in SF starting Monday and would love to dive into this.

We've been remiss in collecting updates thus far (the focus was building the best early-stage portfolio possible) but we need this to understand what's going on, to add value effectively, and to run a good follow-on strategy.

We should rope in Arthur as well since it's all linked to the CRM infra we're building.

On Thu, Jul 31, 2025 at 7:44 AM Chris York <c@chrisyork.co> wrote:

> I'm not a Google Workspace admin expert, but I believe there are basically
two ways to do this if you want them to have bespoke email addresses. The
way mentioned earlier is something like updates+paul@, updates+josh@, etc
as a *s*ingle email address, where "updates@" is the actual email address
and Gmail ignores anything after the "+". That approach is the simplest,
but these aren't separate addresses.

Option 1: Google Groups
<https://support.google.com/a/answer/9400082?hl=en&src=supportwidget0&authuser=0#zippy=%2Cstep-create-a-group>
- Like having an individual business Gmail account, the address can be
anything we want
- Can forward emails to whoever you want by either adding them as a member
of the group or setting up some kind of API
<https://support.google.com/a/answer/10427204?sjid=8431625313676321847-NC&authuser=0>
automation
- Groups *can* have a shared inbox, but in this case, we'd probably not
enable that and simply use them as forwarding addresses
- Cannot send emails
- No direct way for founder to change the alias once created (at least to
my knowledge)
- Does not cost money
- Probably more platform risk that Google makes breaking changes or shuts
this down

Option 2: Individual Google Workspace Accounts
- You have to pay $12-25/mo for each individual account
- Richer automation potential down the road
- None of the limitations of the above

Both should be somewhat easy to automate via APIs (will have to
double-check, but quick skim suggests we can create accounts automatically
and set up forwarding easily). The more fun part is the AI parsing the
updates and doing stuff with that.

If you want to get started on this, we'd probably need: 1) a Powerset
Google Workspace account that has full admin access, 2) an Oauth client
with directory/identity/admin API scopes (which we can set up in Google
Cloud with the former, and 3) a list of the emails (v1 attempt here
<https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1SARhmfN_Vy254HvMyQihI-dE4LW1i6m_9B86eXvue84/edit?gid=265942279#gid=265942279>
).

—Chris

On July 30, 2025 at 10:31 PM, Jake Zeller (jake@powerset.co) wrote:

Sorry for the late reply while I've been offline!

Yes, this is exactly what we need to do.

Ideally we could create individually-branded emails for each founder. For
example, Paul already has an email for this he created on his own:
copple.invest@gmail.com
On Tue, Jul 22, 2025 at 6:21 AM Chris York <c@chrisyork.co> wrote:

Great idea.

We built a couple workflows for "Helping" previously, where it basically
parsed individual asks out of investor update emails and created tasks for
the AI agent to research using the CRM as a tool. So for example, founder A
asks for CMO intros, the AI can access (or research) details about founder
A's company/customers/marketing, then run a search through the CRM and
output a draft email to the founder with possible intros for them to
approve. Obviously someone manually double-checks the names/LinkedIns
before hitting send. I think this is a great use case. The v2 would be
picking up on implied needs that aren't explicitly in the updates, e.g. job
posts from their website/social or potential customer intros from the CRM
matching their implied ICP.

A minor tactical thing might be whether to create 20-40 separate emails
vs. having one email (maybe with aliases, e.g. updates+paul@powerset.co where
Gmail ignores stuff after the +). Probably a lot less operational overhead
but a little more stress on the routing logic.

A variant of this might also involve creating an email that portco
founders can message when they want an intro outside the window of the
investor updates. Not sure how much it would be utilized, but it might be
cool to query the CRM via AI agent that way, since it feels less like
you're bothering someone or using social capital if it's just an AI. In
theory, you want the lowest information frictions possible so they can get
intros to relevant customers/talent/etc as early as possible. We'd need to
be more confident in the AI's performance though, and then maybe have a
human review/greenlight the requests if the portco founder finds one they
like and wants to connect. I think 776 has a web UI version of this.

doing read/write to the CRM or requires a new object type (e.g. tasks
and/or comms), although Carlos could spin up the email parsing and LLM
extraction separately if we had a couple example update emails that cover

**Email Summary:** 
Jake Zeller from Powerset agrees to create individually-branded emails for each founder to facilitate better monitoring and support through investor updates. Chris York proposes building an AI-powered system to parse founder update emails, extract requests, and automate drafting intro emails from CRM data, with human oversight to ensure quality. They discuss managing email logistics between multiple branded emails versus aliasing. Future versions may allow founders to request intros via an AI-enabled email, reducing friction. Coordination with Arthur is suggested if CRM modifications are needed, while Carlos could start email parsing and LLM extraction once example emails are provided.

---  

# Autodelegator AI Action Items 

**Action Items (Detected):**
Coordinate with Arthur regarding CRM read/write access or new object types if needed for the AI system. Provide Carlos with example investor update emails covering all three use cases to begin email parsing and large language model (LLM) extraction development. Decide on the preferred email management approach (multiple individual emails vs. single email with aliases) and communicate it to the team.

**Above and Beyond Action Items (Optional):**
1. Develop a prototype dashboard in Airtable or Notion that visualizes parsed founder requests and AI-suggested intros for quick review by Chris and team.

2. Investigate integrating the AI email parsing system with CRM analytics to generate regular reports on top angel investors acknowledged and actionable portfolio insights.

3. Explore automating initial human review triggers in the workflow using N8n based on confidence scores from the AI agent to optimize operational efficiency.

---

**Original Email:** 
Sorry for the late reply while I've been offline!

Yes, this is exactly what we need to do.

Ideally we could create individually-branded emails for each founder. For example, Paul already has an email for this he created on his own: copple.invest@gmail.com
On Tue, Jul 22, 2025 at 6:21 AM Chris York <c@chrisyork.co> wrote:

> Great idea.

We built a couple workflows for "Helping" previously, where it basically
parsed individual asks out of investor update emails and created tasks for
the AI agent to research using the CRM as a tool. So for example, founder A
asks for CMO intros, the AI can access (or research) details about founder
A's company/customers/marketing, then run a search through the CRM and
output a draft email to the founder with possible intros for them to
approve. Obviously someone manually double-checks the names/LinkedIns
before hitting send. I think this is a great use case. The v2 would be
picking up on implied needs that aren't explicitly in the updates, e.g. job
posts from their website/social or potential customer intros from the CRM
matching their implied ICP.

A minor tactical thing might be whether to create 20-40 separate emails
vs. having one email (maybe with aliases, e.g. updates+paul@powerset.co
where Gmail ignores stuff after the +). Probably a lot less operational
overhead but a little more stress on the routing logic.

A variant of this might also involve creating an email that portco
founders can message when they want an intro outside the window of the
investor updates. Not sure how much it would be utilized, but it might be
cool to query the CRM via AI agent that way, since it feels less like
you're bothering someone or using social capital if it's just an AI. In
theory, you want the lowest information frictions possible so they can get
intros to relevant customers/talent/etc as early as possible. We'd need to
be more confident in the AI's performance though, and then maybe have a
human review/greenlight the requests if the portco founder finds one they
like and wants to connect. I think 776 has a web UI version of this.
Something to think about for v2/3, maybe.

This seems like something we'd want to coordinate with Arthur if it's
doing read/write to the CRM or requires a new object type (e.g. tasks
and/or comms), although Carlos could spin up the email parsing and LLM
extraction separately if we had a couple example update emails that cover
all 3 of the use cases.

—Chris

## Email

**Datetime**:
2025-07-10 9:57 PM America/New_York

**From**:
Accounts Payable <ap@athenago.com>

**To**:


**Body**:
Good day!

  
Hope you are doing well.

  
This is a gentle reminder regarding the credit card liquidation for you or your cardholder for the period **June 5, 2025 to July 4, 2025**_._ 

Kindly fill out the[ expense tracker](https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1pbfq7f8NJ4Y0SXBs4NOugJ8h5ahbiw7y88XqPq2fMjw/edit#gid=0) with your itemized transactions and send it via [Credit Card Expense Report Form.](https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLScUapXHo8X4t2iK2syuHkpsD270GukknqSivjFxhkpWLUFBTQ/viewform)

  
_Note: For C-suites, If the monthly credit card expense report is $5,000 and below, there is no need to route it to the CEO for approval. To complete the liquidation submission, the C-suite cardholder must acknowledge the expense report via email, and his/her XP uploads the copy through the mentioned form._

Please be informed that the statement cut-off date is every 5th of the month. Hence, the deadline for submitting credit card liquidation is every 15th of the month.

  
We appreciate your compliance by **Tuesday**. Kindly disregard this email if you have already submitted it.

  
For more information about our corporate credit card liquidation process, kindly take the time to read our [policy](https://drive.google.com/file/d/1gkKrPKlLFkMR3TRA3V7a575SYWEbTlcq/view).

  
Should you have any questions or concerns, please let us know.

  
Warm regards,

  
\--  

Accounts Payable                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      
 -
Finance Department, Athena

## Notes
- You may have to set up both c@chrisyork.co and ea@chrisyork.co accounts (unless one is out of credits). If both are low, only create account with c@.
* Website to set up account is: https://enrichlayer.com/transition?from_proxycurl=true
* Info below
* Update n8n workflows if any are actively used or likely to be turned on; if not, don't bother
    * [This one](https://n8n.chrisyork.co/workflow/zzAWPrf6WioFK6Pr) seems most worth updating based on what I can tell

---

## Welcome Proxycurl customers! We are Enrich Layer

- Your login, API keys, and credit card information don't change
* Your credits are fully transferred from Proxycurl
* You get a bonus set of credits: we'll match your first top-up with us up to $500
* Price matching guarantee for 24 months

Simply change your API base URL
from https://nubela.co/proxycurl/api to https://enrichlayer.com/api/v2

For specific endpoint path mappings, please have a look at the [docs](https://enrichlayer.com/docs/pc/#transition-guide-transition-from-proxycurl-to-enrichlayer).

- Do we need a new API key, or will our current Proxycurl key still work?
    - Your existing Proxycurl key is already whitelisted at Enrich Layer. No new key needed.
- Will my invoices still show "Proxycurl", or does billing migrate to Enrich Layer immediately?
    - Invoices starting from July will come from Enrich Layer
- Is the data schema 100% identical, or should I expect subtle field-level differences?
    * Request and response schemas are byte-to-byte identical; no field renames or type changes, with the exception of groups, inferred_salary, and gender.

See our [API documentation](https://enrichlayer.com/docs/pc/) for complete details, including a [section on the transition](https://enrichlayer.com/docs/pc/#transition-guide).

Thanks, Enrich Layer Team

On Tue, Jul 1, 2025 at 5:46 PM Chris York <chrisyork@athena.com> wrote:

> Oh, so we don't do the separate queries per client/company area anymore,
since we migrated our stuff to the Exa /research endpoint. We only do one
query now, which is what was included in the other email. In the old setup,
the 3-5 queries were basically the JSON keys/descriptions for each part of
the response output and parts of the main prompt in the single Exa query
now.

So for example, for a company query, we would use the first part of the
main Exa research prompt and then the JSON part for a section like
"overview and evolution" below:

You are a **market research analyst**. Produce a comprehensive report on
**Spruce ID**, ensuring every fact refers to the correct firm only.

<COMPANY>
- **Name:** Spruce ID
- **Site:** https://spruceid.com/
- **Description:** SpruceID helps organizations issue AI-resistant digital
identity credentials, such as mobile driver's licenses, with built-in
security, privacy protection, and observability.
</COMPANY>

Study its evolution, market stance, customer acquisition, and growth.

## Company Overview and Evolution
Founding details, key milestones, product features, and growth indicators.
Use bullet points for founding details and milestones, present growth
indicators in summarized paragraphs with source citations.
Then we'd do all the 5 sections of the company deep research JSON schema
as separate queries like the above, and pass the 5 outputs to Gemini 2.5
Flash to summarize.

In other words, the Exa main prompt + JSON output schema contains all the
separate queries we originally made, when we did them as individual
searches. You have all the prompts we used, it's just a matter of doing it
as a single research task vs 5 separate queries for lower costs/better
efficiency vs tradeoffs in thoroughness..

--Chris

queries are about the person, and half are about the company (3-5 queries

Hey,

Apologies for the delay on the API keys; Carlos was supposed to send these
yesterday, but I'll make sure he does so today. Most of the services have
free plans with sufficiently generous limits to build a test app, and some
may not allow me to make more than one active key, so you may want to get

re: Deep Research Prompts
These were provided in the previous email for Wayne Chang and Spruce ID
(along with example output for the exact queries). They used the older
version where we did not scrape LinkedIn first for previous companies/work
history and only use a short description of the company from scraping their
URL, but you could easily adjust it to include the other companies and
LinkedIn data. The data for Wayne is correct despite having a somewhat
common name, likely because his company is reasonably well-publicized. The
deep research flow can be accurate even with little information, everything
is just about probabilities.

re: Overall Flow

- You certainly can do deep research on the client without the
person's LinkedIn URL or personal URL (as we did with Wayne), the risk of
the information being wrong is simply higher
- Since this is intended for the XP, they should probably double-check
the details regardless; not only is this a good practice to avoid issues
with LLM inaccuracies, it's just nice homework for an XP with a new client
in general to read the source content
- I would probably say you need either LinkedIn URL OR personal URL
AND a non-blank company URL to trust the general web research, regardless
of Exa/Firecrawl/Perplexity
- Deep research on the company is less risky and less dependent on
the other data points; as long as you have company domain, you can probably
just s

On Tue, Jun 24, 2025 at 9:03 PM Chris York <chrisyork@athena.com> wrote:

> Just to clarify:
> The user context columns are all text—they are *not* JSONB where you
> would filter for specific keys/values within them. So the data retrieved
> and injected into the prompts are all strings.
> *Example*
> [image: CleanShot 2025-06-25 at 11.44.02@2x.png]
> Some of the user's preferences are *converted* into a JSON payload for
> SerpAPI (for example, a preference for certain amenities would be converted
> to a numeric ID that Google Hotels uses). But their preferences are not
> *stored* as JSON. For testing, we essentially put exactly what exists in
> Supabase within the context threads, so what you see there reflects what
> the AI is working with when it makes tool calls using this data. The
> response returned from SerpAPI for flights, hotels, etc is JSON, and that
> data is passed to the subsequent prompts.
> We considered a setup where there are some JSONB columns and the AI can
> filter these for specific details, but that was intended for later. Most
> user context columns are 1-10k characters, so that was considered
> unnecessary at this stage. It could definitely make sense in scenarios like
> a mini-CRM or recent files or recent calls column, where the AI could
> filter for a specific person or something like that. Maybe it even makes
> sense for hotels or flights, if there were separate preference sections for
> business/personal trips or domestic/international trips, etc. In theory,
> that could reduce costs or reduce the likelihood the AI makes a mistake in
> applying the preferences. But as of right now, all columns are text and
> formatted in markdown.
> --Chris
> On June 24, 2025 at 6:03 PM, Ann Javellana (ann@chrisyork.co) wrote:
> Hi Kanishk,
> Ann here, one of Chris’ EAs. As an example of how we handle client
> context inside our tools, I’ve attached the hotel-search TypeScript file
> and its small progress component:
>    - google-hotels.ts – main tool
>    - hotel.tsx – progress UI
> *How the tool uses the context_hotels profile*
>    - *Reads preferences at the start - *getUserContext() pulls the
>    traveler’s JSON record (budget, brands, amenities, etc.) as soon as the
>    tool runs.
>    - *Adds that JSON to the first prompt - *The LLM prompt that turns
>    “Find three hotels near SoHo” into structured search parameters includes a
>    <Client_Context> block with those preferences, so the search itself
>    reflects them.
>    - *Re-ranks with the same data - *After results return, the tool
>    applies the preferences again to sort and filter the shortlist before
>    sending it back.
>    - *Shows progress without exposing data - *While it works, the tool
>    emits events like “Getting hotel preferences…”; hotel.tsx simply displays
>    those messages and never touches the preference JSON.
> *Why we keep preferences inside the tool*
>    - The EA doesn’t have to remember client details—preferences are
>    applied automatically.
>    - Sensitive data stays out of the global prompt and chat history.
>    - Each domain (hotels, flights, gifts, etc.) has its own tool and
>    context field, keeping code paths clear and separate.
>    - I built this in *Cursor* for quick navigation between schema,
>    types, and tests.
> Best,
> Ann
> On Tue, Jun 24, 2025 at 2:30 PM Kanishk Kalra <kanishk.kalra@athena.com>
> wrote:
> Hi Chris,
> Thanks for such a detailed response. This is really helpful. Will let you
> know if I have more questions.
> Best,
> Kanishk
> On Mon, Jun 23, 2025 at 23:24 Chris York <chrisyork@athena.com> wrote:
> Hey,
> The memory features are not as robust as we would like, or set up in an
> ideal way. I'll describe exactly how they work, but that's not necessarily
> meant to be implementation guidance for a more mature or resourced product.
>    - *Basic Working Memory*
>    - The most recent X messages from both the user and AI are included
>       in the system prompt, and this is not limited to the active thread (recent
>       messages in the same thread are flagged differently, and all recent
>       messages are grouped by thread name for clarity)
>       - *Thread/Message Memory Retrieval Tool*
>    - The AI has a tool to search previous threads/messages; this tool is
>       more like a multi-grep with some fancy logic rails vs letting the model
>       create its own searches fully
>       - The system prompts make it very clear that it should always use
>       this tool if it seems like prior context is implied, particularly if the
>       topic does not match one of the context columns we build during the
>       onboarding functions
>       - We do not use a vector database of any kind, in any scenario
>       - If you observe the AI's memory to be functioning well, it is
>       almost certainly involving this tool if there is higher than usual latency
>       vs. quick messages (although this tool uses the fastest LLMs we can and DB
>       reads are pretty quick)
>       - *User C

shipping the V1, but it has some good general concepts and enabled the AI
to perform quite well with things like personalized flight/hotel search and
assisting with company-relayed requests. Embedding memory sections in tools
and making the various memory types available as data which can be
retrieved from a tool also seemed to work well. There are probably many
other types of memory topics that could be retrieved / assembled with a
similar workflow to the ones we've shared.

Most of the workflows that derive context + create the "memory" for the
app are built in n8n, and while you can export JSON files of these and ask
an LLM to convert to a function, these are a little messy.
The vast majority of the workflows are basically as follows:
Run search query in Gmail (or Drive, or pull recent calendar events)

Filter the results

Run through 1 or more LLM prompts to extract/clean data and/or create
memory summary
The code to hit the Gmail or Drive API would probably not be very
instructive for you, and there are like a dozen of the same basic workflow,
so I think porting the queries/filters/prompts to a Google Sheet might be
an easier way for you to get a sense of how things work.

send it over.

On Tue, Jun 10, 2025 at 8:20 PM Chris York <chrisyork@athena.com> wrote:
Hi Vasu,
First off, great to be connected! I don't think we were formally introduced, and I've heard nothing but great things about you.
I'm grateful you took the time to play around with our prototype. To answer a few of your questions and provide other context:
The Y-1 model definitely has higher latency; there are a lot of low-hanging fruit here, but we were really focused on validating other hypotheses for the V1 (e.g. around automated context extraction, tools, etc), so appreciate your patience with this + other polish issues
Memory or context injection is actually not the biggest lever here, incidentally, although per-user prompt caching w/ some of the context would be moderately helpful—Shortwave does this to great effect
Most of the user context available to the system is injected only during tool calls
For example, if the model receives a request related to booking a flight, it calls a tool where the Postgres column with user flight preferences is passed in the context to an LLM at two points: 1) to populate parameters for flight search API (e.g. "always flies business class"), and 2) to filter/sort the available flights and pass the response back to the main tool

There is also a tool where the AI can decide if it needs additional context, and it basically gets a list of column names and can retrieve one or more columns from that tool before using another one (e.g. review deep research on user's company before using Firecrawl/Exa to research competitors)

There is no RAG tool for it to check emails, calendar, or drive at this time
The "the model keeps waiting even after the response is complete and refuses to accept new queries" issue is a known bug
Our main goal here was not to build a production-ready application for rollout with all the XPs, but to build a playground where we can experiment and validate certain hypotheses related to AI augmentation or performance of common workflows.
The first of these was the notion that a great deal of context about the client can be found via certain AI workflows and would improve the usefulness of the tool. This seems to be accurate; at least, my own XPs report the flight search and hotel search are very useful since the preferences are baked in. They also believe that they would've benefitted a great deal from the other context summaries like email thread analysis and network context if they hadn't already worked with me for a long time. I've seen the current format of Athena client user manuals, and the context we have extracted in various domains here seems to be an order of magnitude more useful to an XP on day 1.
The second is the automatic identification of tasks. We do this as a daily cron job that reviews recent email threads, edited files in Drive, and meetings. Then, the AI pushes some suggestions in a daily thread, which has some hidden context about those tasks in the system prompt and should enable the XPs to easily tackle the suggestions (if accurate). This is quite behind the other features in terms of the attention its received, but we believe it's a promising angle. I have a much more sophisticated workflow personally where tasks are pulled from my emails, call transcripts, calendar, drive, and other sources to have an AI autodelegate tasks to our project management SaaS. We scoped this down for V1, partly due to it needing less validation. This is probably

## Update - Jun 11, 2025 10:36:48
- Fixed issue where errors were caused by missing a limit to one email (Missive conversation matching to Gmail subject)
	* [Error](https://n8n.chrisyork.co/workflow/cnbCWgDj2ngb6nM5/executions/1614280): Problem in node 'Missive - Get Message IDs' - The service is receiving too many requests from you
* Added limit to 1 node and also set "Missive - Get Message IDs" to only execute once
* Could cause errors if more than one email is retrieved from Gmail simultaneously; monitor this

---

## Notes
- This workflow was causing high CPU load because it ran every minute
* We edited the workflow to simplify it, removing at least 8 LLM calls and several other nodes
* The workflow logic used "first()" a lot, which will not work if it runs every 15 minutes, since there will be more than one item
* It has not been tested, and there may be errors
* Errors relating to "first()" changing to "item" may be resolved by find() or filter() formulas to grab the right item by matching against Gmail ID, Missive ID, etc
* Alternatively, we can probably do loops where it runs the whole workflow with one item at a time
* The two LLM prompts should be rewritten and condensed
* Other LLM prompts could potentially be revised
* The autodrafter part was disconnected for now
* We are using stricter filtering, so it may fire less often
* Eventually this should be a sub-workflow called by the autodelegator V4 / labeler

On Tue, Jun 10, 2025 at 8:20 PM Chris York <chrisyork@athena.com> wrote:
Hi Vasu,

First off, great to be connected! I don't think we were formally introduced, and I've heard nothing but great things about you.

I'm grateful you took the time to play around with our prototype. To answer a few of your questions and provide other context:

The Y-1 model definitely has higher latency; there are a lot of low-hanging fruit here, but we were really focused on validating other hypotheses for the V1 (e.g. around automated context extraction, tools, etc), so appreciate your patience with this + other polish issues

Memory or context injection is actually not the biggest lever here, incidentally, although per-user prompt caching w/ some of the context would be moderately helpful—Shortwave does this to great effect

Most of the user context available to the system is injected only during tool calls

For example, if the model receives a request related to booking a flight, it calls a tool where the Postgres column with user flight preferences is passed in the context to an LLM at two points: 1) to populate parameters for flight search API (e.g. "always flies business class"), and 2) to filter/sort the available flights and pass the response back to the main tool
There is also a tool where the AI can decide if it needs additional context, and it basically gets a list of column names and can retrieve one or more columns from that tool before using another one (e.g. review deep research on user's company before using Firecrawl/Exa to research competitors)
There is no RAG tool for it to check emails, calendar, or drive at this time

The "the model keeps waiting even after the response is complete and refuses to accept new queries" issue is a known bug
Our main goal here was not to build a production-ready application for rollout with all the XPs, but to build a playground where we can experiment and validate certain hypotheses related to AI augmentation or performance of common workflows.

The first of these was the notion that a great deal of context about the client can be found via certain AI workflows and would improve the usefulness of the tool. This seems to be accurate; at least, my own XPs report the flight search and hotel search are very useful since the preferences are baked in. They also believe that they would've benefitted a great deal from the other context summaries like email thread analysis and network context if they hadn't already worked with me for a long time. I've seen the current format of Athena client user manuals, and the context we have extracted in various domains here seems to be an order of magnitude more useful to an XP on day 1.

The second is the automatic identification of tasks. We do this as a daily cron job that reviews recent email threads, edited files in Drive, and meetings. Then, the AI pushes some suggestions in a daily thread, which has some hidden context about those tasks in the system prompt and should enable the XPs to easily tackle the suggestions (if accurate). This is quite behind the other features in terms of the attention its received, but we believe it's a promising angle. I have a much more sophisticated workflow personally where tasks are pulled from my emails, call transcripts, calendar, drive, and other sources to have an AI autodelegate tasks to our project management SaaS. We scoped this down for V1, partly due to it needing less validation. This is probably amongst the highest leverage tech assets the company could build, and we've spent enough time on it previously to know that it's very feasible from an implementation & AI capabilities standpoint.

There is a third hypothesis around "workflows as tools." This is somewhat embedded in the implementation of the hotel and flight tools, but we are bullish that a lot of common XP workflows and artifacts can have their best practices & overall process baked into a mostly deterministic workflow with a little AI sprinkled in. This reduces the need to train XPs to be really good at some specific task, like writing a meeting bio or building a prospect list or whatever, and there could be industry-specific ones based on the client. We also may be able

| [![](https://camo.missiveusercontent.com/c33a3d8587727572deb61d310e677e98b7305418/68747470733a2f2f6272617a652d696d616765732e636f6d2f617070626f792f636f6d6d756e69636174696f6e2f6173736574732f696d6167655f6173736574732f696d616765732f3632313731383662303130323463336361336230306639332f6f726967696e616c2e706e673f31363435363830373437) ](https://ablink.news.gemini.com/ls/click?upn=u001.SWvH-2F-2Fdx6zPyhExSMoloFTqPVbh-2BnSlChjqI74yRFCY-3DlIWb%5FFM80vhtvE5FhxfbS-2BQq5neh6Fm1TRPfOg-2F32Yl8aC2eLGNMwEN6xs6RlpGPBUzRbhDRxDCKhysjjeGbdmvMqH0MYn6djAS7emou-2BeUkKKCeHxDTvO79C8OK5ZKweRmR5n7-2B5gRJ6dEUPO3gghxEhQDzY12X2Yhu7wzJV8y7-2B7IAHUqfutvcnSuQqC4we9kJzGMIgAyAoEX2zP7-2Bk-2B660SXqS2dUDslQiVN3oxA0-2Fa-2BMJ4fAZY-2BF6tfFMwtr25h7-2FLaN8klEZYSanUGCBYhi42UDXyjlV7-2FDYRzL3pu0GP50BpRjRv5-2FDNl8i-2FcCC6SwCKue5ApwwfgWiM9m6QrfhkAcYOf8H2sqgV0rf-2FBVezRPo-2BDleV5h505P-2FmzoJnRT4e9nVYRzGMrW7D0-2F7jkBLTYvCh6CJfDRI8cB7OJOqwPumGtLpX-2FD0S5vBg6EEr-2BddGGiwF6-2FuE1fWReBuTrA5jCe5dsLWpLWJMDjpOLb9r0oRuYpv1zz5FM2jiYNfC4uddR4hBPUZtmV4YE2GCxpi397ot0jf-2BLqKTEqZ7fXtQZE-2B1XylYxLix7pRXw8ZG0-2B1WYjeJx5lX6UM9l8CENc9ev47TkaqOW7dKH4Lm9ZZ3Dp0bWk01IrvWdH0qm5tn9fyECrHxzC0o1vjYLlCZ6suToFk5BjSE4QccaQnEaaTbY2oQEpfDWeT8yBk2DDIGf2KESRK6yR1JB7BP3DJXRnxUQ-3D-3D) Hi Christopher, In a continued effort to provide our customers with additional control and security, Gemini recently introduced the ability to allowlist IPs at the API key level.   **We are requiring customers to take the below actions on their Trading API keys by June 30, 2025 to prevent an interruption in service.** **Who needs to take action?** All clients using Trading API keys for both REST and FIX. Customers who use Trading API keys for Auditor, Admin, or Fund Management functions will also need to take action. **What do I need to do?** Please update your existing Trading API key settings by assigning Trusted IPs or choosing Unrestricted access by   **Monday, June 30, 2025 at 9 pm ET.** If you do not complete this action by this time, any new API calls will be automatically rejected until this action is completed. **Do I have to set Trusted IPs for my Trading API keys?** No, if you would prefer not to assign Trusted IPs to your API keys, you may select Unrestricted access for your API keys. **How do I select Trusted IPs for my API keys or set them to be Unrestricted?** After signing in to your Gemini app on web or mobile, go to _Settings_ \> _API_ and navigate to the _ellipsis_ of your existing API key(s) and click _Edit_. Select _Trusted IPs_ and add the list of IP addresses that you will use to call Gemini’s APIs. Alternatively, if you do not wish to select Trusted IPs, you can choose to select Unrestricted. Save these new API key settings for all your existing API keys by June 30, 2025 at 9 pm ET to ensure no disruption to future API calls. **Please Note:** If you are an API user with group-level or account-level access, you will need to take these actions for each account you oversee. If you access your API with a VPN, you will likely want to select Unrestricted access unless you are 100% certain of the policies by which your provider assigns IPs. If you have IP allowlisting enabled already at the group-level or account-level, and choose to add Trusted IPs at the API level, the Trusted IPs will need to match, or be a subset of the existing group-level or account-level IPs. Any newly created API key will require you to select your API Key level security (allowlisted IPs or unrestricted) at the time of generation. You can find further information in our FAQ [here](https://ablink.news.gemini.com/ls/click?upn=u001.SWvH-2F-2Fdx6zPyhExSMoloFXvqVvH8jisRXrD4dPHB9WCskLFRdUTuBTKAfqc2CU1ZPOBXbWrZxePRtBPjkEWkCAM5xU3yR9tBL2oU5MpOc5c5JoBdx7U-2FmMQbtp1ruKQg92biMYgo00-2FYoRpVAUW6EaiVci6HXPlPbWfpT5zrxaM-3D0pn0%5FFM80vhtvE5FhxfbS-2BQq5neh6Fm1TRPfOg-2F32Yl8aC2eLGNMwEN6xs6RlpGPBUzRbhDRxDCKhysjjeGbdmvMqH0MYn6djAS7emou-2BeUkKKCeHxDTvO79C8OK5ZKweRmR5n7-2B5gRJ6dEUPO3gghxEhQDzY12X2Yhu7wzJV8y7-2B7IAHUqfutvcnSuQqC4we9kJzGMIgAyAoEX2zP7-2Bk-2B660SXqS2dUDslQiVN3oxA0-2Fa-2BMJ4fAZY-2BF6tfFMwtr25h7-2FLaN8klEZYSanUGCBYhi42UDXyjlV7-2FDYRzL3pu0GP50BpRjRv5-2FDNl8i-2FcCC6SwCKue5ApwwfgWiM9m6QrfhkAcYOf8H2sqgV0rf-2FBVezRPo-2BDleV5h505P-2FmzoJnRT4e9nVYRzGMrW7D0-2F7jkBLTYvCh6CJfDRI8cB7OJOqwPumGtLpX-2FD0S5vBg6EEr-2BddGGiwF6-2FuE1fWReBuTrA5jCe5dsLWpLWJMDjpOLb9r0oRuYpv1zz5FM2jiYNfC4uddR4hBPUZtmV4YE2GCxpi397ot0jf-2BLqKTEqZ7fXtQZE-2B1XylYxLix7pRXw8ZG0-2B1WYjeJx5lX6UM9l8CENc9em3qcZ2oVKswzYARpxdHkwV6LkDv1hEUTspunb2-2FdG7dWOLUuC0V3BwTu0dDO9cnWAQVNLQZ46PMpjUf4p7wrJeePxIicvh61CWgxwyu0V4NdjZ7pyCqg2siA3-2BSdEaIBg-3D-3D).
